Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Silvia Carreno-Coll: Initial Appearance as to Raymond Cruz- Serrano(1), Sheila Matos-Sandoval(4), Nelson Benitez-Benitez(5), Angel D. Olmo-Diaz(7), Carlos Cruz-Centeno(9), Gustavo Baez- Castro(12), Willie Ray Torres-Reyes(16), Jesus Martinez-Nieves(17) held on 2/28/2013. Defendants were provided with copy of the Indictment and advised as to the charges and their rights. After reviewing the CJA-23 forms filled by defendants, the Court deemed it appropriate to appoint counsel. Defendants will be represented by CJA counsel. Defendants ordered temporarily detained pending hearings. Arraignment/Detention set for 3/5/2013 at 1:30 PM in Courtroom 8 before US Magistrate Judge Silvia Carreno- Coll. USPO Carolina Aparicio. (amr) (Entered: 03/01/2013)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Silvia Carreno-Coll: Initial Appearance as to Nicolas Marrero- Matos(8), Luz V. Romero-Vaello(11), Luis J. Pizarro-Ortiz(13), Melvin Martinez-Santiago(19), Christopher Isaac-Nieves(20), Ian E. Huertas-Santiago(23) held on 2/28/2013. Defendants were provided with copy of the Indictment and advised as to the charges and their rights. After reviewing the CJA-23 forms filled by defendants, the Court deemed it appropriate to appoint counsel. Defendants will be represented by CJA counsel, except #13 and #20. Defendant #13 - Luis Pizarro-Ortiz informed that will retain the services of Attorney Jorge Armenteros. As to defendant #20 Christopher Isaac-Nieves, the Court will appoint FPD, defendant is being represented by FPD in CR-12-125 (DRD). Defendants ordered temporarily detained pending hearings. Arraignment/Bail set for 3/14/2013 at 9:00 AM in Courtroom 8 before US Magistrate Judge Silvia Carreno-Coll. USPO Carolina Aparicio. (amr) (Entered: 03/01/2013)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Silvia Carreno-Coll: Arraignment and Detention Hearings as to Luis O. Martinez-Nieves (33) Count 1,2-5 held on 3/5/2013. AUSA Cesar Rivera and defense counsel Johnny Rivera were present. As to Arraignment, the Court finds defendant competent at this time. Defendant waived the reading of the Indictment. Plea of Not Guilty is entered. Defense is granted seven (7) days to obtain discovery and fourteen (14) days thereafter to file all motions. The case is referred to the Judge for trial setting thereafter. The Government provided discovery to defense counsel today. As to Detention, defense counsel proffered that defendant is willing to relocate with his mother, is self-employed as a fashion designer and may work from the home and moved for bail to be set. The Government proffered defendant's role and/or participation and moved for detention. After hearing the parties, the Court set bond as to Luis O. Martinez-Nieves (33) in the amount of $10,000 secured. Bonding company will be allowed. Standard release conditions, third party custodian of stepfather to be qualified, employment from home, drug testing and treatment, home detention, and not enter or get near the Ernesto Ramos-Antonini public housing project are all imposed. Defense counsel informed that defendant 1s asthmatic and needs medication, that is: Proventil. Defendant also snores very loud and probably is related to his condition. Metropolitan Detention Center should look into this for evaluation. Notice for medical condition was previously sent to MDC. (MDC by e-mail) (Court Reporter FTR/bg.) Hearing set for 01:30. Hearing held at 02:05. Hearing ended at 02:34. Interpreter Olga Uribe. (br) (Entered: 03/08/2013)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Silvia Carreno-Coll: Bail Hearing as to Luz V. Romero-Vaello held on 3/14/2013. AUSA Cesar Rivera and defense counsel Joseph C. Laws was present. Defense counsel was heard by proffer. The Court addressed counsel Mara Perez, who is representing the family in the state court hearing in reference to defendant's minors. Defendant was heard on allocution. The Government was heard by proffer, moved for detention and presented two video recordings. One video shows her carrying a firearm and the other video shows her stabbing a female, for which she was sentenced for attempted murder. After hearing the parties, the Court finds that the weight of the evidence is heavy, that defendant's state sentence may possibly be revoked, that there are no conditions of release that can be crafted and ordered defendant detained without bail pending trial. (Court Reporter FTR/bg.) Hearing set for 09:00. Hearing held at 10:29. Hearing ended at 10:57. Interpreter Edna Brayfield. (br) (Entered: 03/14/2013)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Silvia Carreno-Coll: Arraignment and Detention Hearings as to Eric Benitez-Fernandez (41) Count 1,2-5 held on 4/1/2013. AUSA Timothy Henwood and defense counsel Manuel Moraza were present. As to Arraignment, the Court finds defendant competent at this time. Defendant waived the reading of the Indictment. Plea of Not Guilty is entered. Defense is granted seven (7) days to obtain discovery and fourteen (14) days thereafter to file all motions. The case is referred to the Judge for trial setting thereafter. As te Detention, the Government proffered as to defendant's role and/or participation and moved for detention. Defense counsel proffered that relatives were in court, are willing to serve as third party custodians, has strong ties and requested bond. After hearing the parties, the Court set bond as to Eric Benitez-Fernandez (41) in the amount of $10,000 of which $5,000 is cash or secured and $5,000 is unsecured. Bonding company is not allowed. Standard release conditions, qualified third party custodian of a relative to be interviewed and if possible by the brother, electronic monitoring device paid by him, curfew, drug testing and treatment, shall not enter or get near the housing public project, work, reside with brother are all imposed. The Court forewarned defendant to comply with all conditions; otherwise, bail will be revoke. (Court Reporter FTR/bg.) Hearing set for 02:00. Hearing held at 02:31. Hearing ended at 03:00. Interpreter Enith Valdes. (br) (Entered: 04/02/2013)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Silvia Carreno-Coll: Bond Revocation Hearing as to Jervesh Alvarado-Ortiz held on 7/10/2013. AUSA Cesar Rivera and defense counsel Raymond Rivera were present. Defense counsel had the opportunity to speak with the probation officer, with the Government and client. Although there may be a possibility of a drug treatment program, but at this time, defendant does not contest that the violations occurred. The Government requested that defendant be remanded to the custody of the Bureau of Prisons and that bail be revoked. After hearing the parties, the Court ordered the bail revoked. If at any time, defendant is in a better position to assert self imposed controls, together with the probation officer, conditions may be crafted. But at this time, the Court finds no condition or combinations of conditions that would assure the safty of the community. Defendant is ordered detained. (Court Reporter FTR/bg.) Hearing set for 11:00. Hearing held at 11:19. Hearing ended at 11:23. Interpreter Felix Toledo. (br) (Entered: 07/10/2013)

Minute Entry for proceedings was called but not held before US Magistrate Judge Silvia Carreno-Coll: Change of Plea Hearing as to Juan Medina-Lopez held on 1/15/2014. AUSA Cesar Rivera and defense counsel Rafael Anglada were present. Defense counsel informed that defendant is not ready to hold the hearing, since defendant is looking forward for a better plea offer. The Government proffered that defendant was a seller to one of the most violent organizations in which lots of firearms were seized and used ina conspiracy. The offer has been on the table for over six months and the Government will not be lowering the offer. After the Court addressed the defendant, the Court granted defense counsel's request for a continuance of the hearing. If at such time defendant does not plea, the case will be resent to the presiding Judge for trial setting. ORDER denying 677 Motion to Continue as to Samuel Hernandez-Nieves (32): This case was set in February for a sentencing hearing on May 30. Defendant's counsel asks for a continuance, claiming that he has a previous sentence set before Judge Dominguez - however, that sentencing was reset for May 30 just this week. See Crim. No. 12-358, Docket No. 135. Therefore, the sentencing hearing in this case takes precedence over the one set before Judge Dominguez. The Court shall not re-set this sentence; Counsel shall make necessary arrangements in his other case. Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 5/30/2014. (RJC) (Entered: 05/30/2014)

ORDER as to Reynaldo Cruz-Robles (3) noted 767 MOTION in Compliance and Informative Regarding Discovery Provided to Defendant; denying without prejudice 758 MOTION to Suppress. Defendant, in his motion to suppress, alleged that his motion was filed based on the "scant discovery materials" provided by the government, and that he therefore reserved his right to amend the motion once discovery ended. However, the government has informed the Court that it has provided defendant Cruz-Robies with all the discovery in its possession. The Court will therefore DENY without prejudice defendant's motion to suppress. Defendant Cruz- Robles wili have until October 3, 2014 to file a final motion to suppress. No extensions will be granted. Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 9/24/2014.(IL) (Entered: 09/24/2014)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Silvia Carreno-Coll: Change of Plea Hearing as to Raymond Cruz- Serrano (1) held on 10/23/2014. AUSA Cesar Rivera and defense counsel Edwin Prado were present. Defendant was present in court and under custody. Defense counsel requested to withdraw the second and third motions to suppress. Having no objection by the Government, the Court granted the request to withdraw the motions to suppress. Consent was approved, filed and made part of the record. The defendant was found competent to plea. The Magistrate Judge will recommend to the Court that the Plea of Guilty be accepted as to Counts One (1) and Six (6) of the Indictment. At the time of sentencing, the Government will request the dismissal of the remaining counts. The defendant is to remain under custody. The Court ordered the preparation of a presentence report. Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez: Motion Hearing as to Jose R. Levy-Diaz (15) held on 11/7/2014. Present AUSA Cesar Rivera and Atty. Richard Dansoh. The 817 MOTION to Withdraw as Attorney filed by Jose R. Levy-Diaz, pro se, was discussed with the parties and the defendant. The Court stated that defendant raised three grounds in his motion: for lack of visits, lack of discussion of discovery and plea negotiations. The Court did not find merit on any of the three grounds, did not find at all that defendant has been receiving ineffective assistance of counsel, and stated there has been no  breakdown in the communication process. The Court only found that there was a breakdown in the attorney-client relationship based on lack of trust. Therefore, the Court will recommend to the District Judge that a new attorney be appointed to represent the defendant. Counsel Dansoh shall continue with defendant's representation until new counsel is appointed by the Court unless Judge Garcia decides on the contrary. (Court Reporter FTR.)Hearing set for 11:00.Hearing held at 11:00.Hearing ended at 11:49 Interpreter Sonia Crescioni. (ft) (Entered: 11/17/2014)

ORDER as to Victor Vega-Sterling (10) re 1214 Waiver of Presence at Arraignment filed by Victor Vega-Sterling - Approved and plea of not guilty is entered as to ali counts. The parties will have 7 days for discovery and 14 days thereafter to file any motions. Case is referred to Judge Garcia for scheduling. Although counsel stated that at the time of filing they were not in a position to rebut the presumption, the bail hearing cannot be waived. The clerk of court will transfer petitioner's filings to the district court for filing as a § 2255 motion. Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Silvia Carreno-Coll: Change of Plea Hearing as to Victor Vega- Sterling (10) held on 8/12/2016. Present were AUSA Cesar Rivera and defense counsel Rafael Castro-Lang. Defendant was under custody, present in court and did not require the assistance of the Court Interpreter. Consent to proceed before a U. S. Magistrate Judge was filed and accepted in open court. The defendant was found competent to plea. The defendant was advised of the maximum penalties he is facing, his constitutional rights, consequences of waiving his constitutional rights and the applicable statutory guidelines. Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory: Sentencing held on 12/19/2016 for Victor Vega-Sterling (10). AUSA Cesar Rivera and defense counsel Rafael! Castro-Lang were present. Defendant was present, under custody and assisted  by a certified court interpreter. Objections to the PSI Report. Court ordered the correction to the PSIR. Statements in support of mitigation of punishment heard on behalf of the defense. Defendant's allocution was heard. Sentence imposed as to Count(s) 1, 6, Impr Term: 87 months as to Count One and 72 months as to Count Six to be served consecutively with each other for a total imprisonment term of 159 months. SRT: 8 years as to Count One and 5 years as to Count Six to be served concurrently to each other. SMA: $100 as to each count for a total of $200.00. Per request of the government, Count(s) 2-5, are Dismissed. Counsel requested, as a recommendation, that defendant to be considered to be released to home confinement twelve (12) months prior to completion of his sentence. The Court made a recommendation as to that effect. All terms and conditions are specified in the judgment form. The defendant was advised of his right to appeal. (PO Alexandra Estrada.) (Court Reporter Cindy Brown.) Hearing set for 03:00. Hearing held at 03:49. Hearing ended at 04:12. Interpreter Heidi Cazes. (br) (Entered: 12/22/2016)

ORDER as to Sheila Matos-Sandoval (4): NOTED 1702 Informative Motion filed by Sheila Matos-Sandoval; DECLINING TO ADOPT 1722 Report and Recommendation on Amendment 782; GRANTING 1559 Motion to Reduce Sentence - USSC Amendment 782 filed by Sheila Matos-Sandoval. While Defendant was sentenced after November 1, 2014, the Type C plea agreement was executed prior to the effective date of Amendment 782. Defendant would have been entitled to a 2 level reduction pursuant to Amendment 782, had the plea agreement been negotiated a few days later. Therefore, the Court hereby GRANTS Defendant's Motion for Reduction of Sentence pursuant to 18 U.S.C. § 3582 and Amendment 782 of the U.S. Sentencing Guidelines. Amended Judgment shall be entered accordingly. Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 11/9/2017. (MQ) (Entered: 11/09/2017)

Present were AUSA Cesar Rivera, defense counsel Luis Rodriguez and USPO Emanuel Bravo. The defendant was under custody, present in court and assisted by the Court Interpreter. The defendant was found competent to understand the proceedings. He waived the reading of the Indictment and entered a plea of not guilty as to all counts of the Indictment. The Government has 7 days to produce discovery and the defense has 14 days thereafter to file motions. Case is referred to U.S. District Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory for further proceedings. As to bail, the Government moved for detention. Defense counsel stated that at this time they had nothing to offer as to bail but they reserved the right to reopen hearing. Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory:Sentencing held on 3/26/2019 for Rafael Vazquez-Nieves (24).Present were AUSA Kelly Zenon for Cesar Rivera, Defense Counsel Luis A. Rodriguez-Munoz and USPO Alexandra Estrada. The Defendant was present in court, under custody and assisted by a certified court interpreter. Statements in support of mitigation of punishment heard on behalf of the defense. Parties heard. Defendants allocution heard. Defendant was sentence to a term of imprisonment of 24 months as to count one and 60 months as to count six, to be served CONSECUTIVELY with each other, for a total of 84 MONTHS. (That he be given credit to time served since his arrest in Albany, NY on 8/29/2017); SRT of 6 years as to count one and 5 years as to count six, to be served concurrently with each other and SMA of $200.00. Defendant waived to appeal but was advised of his right to appeal. Government requested that remaining count(s) be dismissed. Request granted. Recommendation to the BOP: 1. That defendant be designated to FC] Danbury, CT or Fort Dix, NJ, so that he can be close to his family that live in Albany, NY. 2. That defendant be enrolled in an educational/vocational rehabilitation training program, specifically in electrical and construction courses. (Court Reporter Zulma Ruiz.)Hearing set for 03:00.Hearing held at 03:53.Hearing ended at 04:17.Interpreter Felix Toledo. (su) (Entered: 03/26/2019)

JUDGMENT as to Rafael Vazquez-Nieves (24):, Count(s) 1 and 6: Imprisonment for a term of 24 months as to count one and 60 months as to count six, to be served CONSECUTIVELY with each other, for a total of 84 MONTHS. (That he be given credit to time served since his arrest in Albany, NY on 8/29/2017); SRT of 6 years as to count one and 5 years as to count six, to be served concurrently with each other and SMA of $200.00.; Count(s) 2-5: Dismissed. ORDER as to Raymond Cruz-Serrano (1} GRANTING 1789 MOTION to Reduce Sentence - USSC Amendment 782. While Defendant was sentenced after November 1, 2014, the Type C plea agreement was executed prior to the effective date of Amendment 782. Defendant would have been entitled to a 2 level reduction pursuant to Amendment 782, had the plea agreement been negotiated a few days later. Therefore, the Court hereby GRANTS Defendant's Motion for Reduction of Sentence pursuant to 18 U.S.C. 3582 and Amendment 782 of the U.S. Sentencing Guidelines. Amended Judgment shall be entered accordingly. Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 10/29/2019. (MQ) (Entered: 10/29/2019)

ORDER denying 1828 Motion to Reduce Sentence re Crack Cocaine Offense - 18:3582 as to Reynaldo Cruz-Robles (3). ORDER denying without prejudice 1874 Motion for Release from Custody as to Nicolas Marrero-Matos (8); denying 1875 Motion for Release from Custody as to Nicolas Marrero-Matos (8); noted 1879 Motion in Compliance as to Nicolas Marrero-Matos (8). Defendant has failed to establish that compassionate release is warranted pursuant to 18 U.S.C. 3582(c)(1)(A). Specifically, Defendant has failed to establish: (1) exhaustion of administrative remedies; (2) extraordinary and compelling reasons justifying a reduction in sentence; (3) that he does not pose a danger to the community; and (4) that a sentence reduction is consistent with 18 U.S.C. 3553(a) and the applicable policy statements issued by the Sentencing Commission. Even assuming, without deciding, that the Court may excuse the failure to exhaust administrative remedies, Defendant's motion lacks specific information or evidence supporting the allegations of preexisting health conditions that would increase for Defendant the risks posed by COVID-19 infection beyond the risks posed to the general population, especially considering that Defendant "described himself as a healthy man with no history of serious illnesses" in his presentence interview. See Docket No. 1030 at 15; see also United States v. Raia, 954 F.3d 594, 597 (3d Cir. 2020) ("We do not mean to minimize the risks that COVID-19 poses in the federal prison system... But the mere existence of COVID-19 in society and the possibility that it may spread to a particular prison alone cannot independently justify compassionate release, especially considering BOP's statutory role, and its extensive and professional efforts to curtail the virus's spread."). Defendant may refile the present motion provided he submits evidence to satisfy the requirements of 18 U.S.C. 3582(c)(1) (A). Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 6/11/2020. (MQ) (Entered: 06/11/2020)

ORDER denying without prejudice 1877 Motion to Reduce Sentence as to Ricardo Cruz-Serrano (2); noted 1895 Motion in Compliance as to Ricardo Cruz-Serrano (2). Defendant has failed to establish that compassionate release is warranted pursuant to 18 U.S.C. 3582(c)(1)(A). Specifically, Defendant has failed to establish: (1) exhaustion of administrative remedies; (2) extraordinary and compelling reasons justifying a reduction in sentence; (3) that he does not pose a danger to the community; and (4) that a sentence reduction is consistent with 18 U.S.C. 3553(a) and the applicable policy statements issued by the Sentencing Commission. Even assuming, without deciding, that the Court may excuse the failure to exhaust administrative remedies, Defendant's motion lacks specific information or evidence supporting the allegations of preexisting health conditions that would increase for Defendant the risks posed by COVID-19 infection beyond the risks posed to the general population. See United States v. Raia, 954 F.3d 594, 597 (3d Cir. 2020) ("We do not mean to minimize the risks that COVID-19 poses in the federal prison system... But the mere existence of COVID-19 in society and the possibility that it may spread to a particular prison alone cannot independently justify  compassionate release, especially considering BOP's statutory role, and its extensive and professional efforts to curtail the virus's spread."); United States v. Eberhart, 2020 WL 1450745, at *2 (N.D. Cal. Mar. 25, 2020) ("[A] reduction of sentence due solely to concerns about the spread of COVID-19 is not consistent with the applicable policy statement of the Sentencing Commission as required by § 3582(c)(1)(A)."). Defendant may refile the present motion provided he submits evidence to satisfy the requirements of 18 U.S.C. 3582(c)(1)(A). Moreover, Defendant has failed to show he qualifies for a sentence reduction pursuant to the First Step Act. Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 6/25/2020. (MQ) (Entered: 06/25/2020)

ORDER as to Nicolas Marrero-Matos (8) denying 1897 Motion to Reduce Sentence; denying 1902 Motion for Release from Custody; noted 1910 Motion In Compliance; granting 1918 Motion for Extension of Time to File Response/Reply. Defendant has failed to present any new argument or evidence that would warrant the Court revisiting its prior holding that Defendant failed to establish that compassionate release is warranted pursuant to 18 U.S.C. 3582(c)(1)(A). See Docket No. 1887. While Defendant provided evidence of exhaustion of administrative remedies, he has failed to establish (1) extraordinary and compelling reasons Justifying a reduction in sentence; (2) that he does not pose a danger to the community; and (3) that a sentence reduction is consistent with 18 U.S.C. 3553(a) and the applicable policy statements issued by the Sentencing Commission. "[T]he mere existence of COVID-19 in society and the possibility that it may spread to a particular prison alone cannot independently justify compassionate release, especially considering BOP's statutory role, and its extensive and professional efforts to curtail the virus's spread." United States v. Raia, 954 F.3d 594, 597 (3d Cir. 2020). While COVID-19 is an especially serious threat to individuals with chronic health conditions, Defendant does not even allege any medical condition that would put him at higher risk of complications from exposure to COVID-19. In fact, Defendant "described himself as a healthy man with no history of serious illnesses in his presentence interview, Docket No. 1030 at 15; the BOP has categorized him as "Care 1 - healthy or simple chronic care," Docket No. 1897-1 at 15; and the BOP denied his request for compassionate release in part because he has "no noted medical history [and] is not enrolled in any chronic care clinics," Docket No. 1919-2. Thus, Defendant has failed to establish extraordinary and compelling reasons. Moreover, Defendant has failed to show he does not pose a danger to the community, especially considering (1) his drug and firearm convictions, (11) his leadership role within the drug trafficking organization; and (111) his disciplinary infractions during his imprisonment. See Docket No. 1919 at 1-3, 8-9. Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 8/27/2020. (MQ) (Entered: 08/27/2020)

ORDER as to Raymond Cruz-Serrano (1) denying without prejudice 1908 Motion to Reduce Sentence - First Step Act; noted 1930 Motion in Compliance; granting 1932 Motion for Leave to File Excess Pages; granting 1933 Motion to Restrict. Defendant has failed to meet his burden of establishing that compassionate release is warranted pursuant to 18 U.S.C. 3582(c)(1)(A). Specifically, Defendant has failed to establish: (1) exhaustion of administrative remedies; (2) extraordinary and compelling reasons justifying a reduction in sentence; (3) that he does not pose a danger to the community; and (4) that a sentence reduction is consistent with 18 U.S.C. 3553(a) and the applicable policy statements issued by the Sentencing Commission. Even if the Court were to excuse the failure to exhaust administrative remedies, Defendant's motion lacks specific information and evidence regarding (1) the risk of COVID-19 infection at the facility where he is currently being held, especially considering the BOP's efforts to address the pandemic; and (2) his allegations that he does not pose a danger to the community, considering his drug and firearms convictions, prior arrests, leadership role within the drug trafficking organization (for which he received a 4 level enhancement), and two disciplinary infractions while imprisoned for possession of a hazardous tool and possession of a dangerous weapon. See Docket Nos. 949 at 8; 1920 at 1-3; see also United States v. Raia, 954 F.3d 594, 597 (3d Cir. 2020) ("[T]he mere existence of COVID-19 in society and the possibility that it may spread to a particular prison alone cannot independently justify compassionate release, especially considering BOP's statutory role, and its extensive and professional efforts to curtail the virus's spread."). Defendant has similarly failed to show that a sentence reduction would be consistent with 18 U.S.C. 3553(a) and the applicable policy statements. For these reasons, Defendant's Motion is hereby DENIED without prejudice. Defendant may refile the present motion provided he submits evidence to satisfy the requirements of 18 U.S.C. 3582(c)(1)(A). Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 9/17/2020. (MQ) (Entered: 09/17/2020)

USCA JUDGMENT as to Reynaldo Cruz-Robles (3): Petitioner seeks leave to file a second or successive 28 U.S.C. § 2255 motion based on United States v. Davis, 139 S. Ct. 2319 (2019), and related precedent. The application is DENIED. Thlis]... denial of an authorization... to file a second or successive application shall not be appealable and shall not be the subject of a petition for rehearing or for a writ of certiorari." See 28 U.S.C. § 2244(b)(3)(E). (mcm) (Entered: 12/08/2020)

ORDER denying without prejudice 1943 Order on Motion for Compassionate Release - 18 U.S.C. Section 3582(c)(1)(A) as to Jose L. Sanchez-Ortiz (22); noted 1945 Motion in Compliance as to Jose L. Sanchez-Ortiz (22). Defendant has failed to meet his burden of establishing that compassionate release is warranted pursuant to 18 U.S.C. 3582(c)(1)(A). Specifically, Defendant has failed to establish: (1) exhaustion of administrative remedies; (2) extraordinary and compelling reasons justifying a reduction in sentence; (3) that he does not pose a danger to the community; and (4) that a sentence reduction is consistent with 18 U.S.C. 3553(a) and the applicable policy statements issued by the Sentencing Commission. Even if the Court were to excuse the failure to exhaust administrative remedies, Defendant has failed to provide any evidence of the alleged extraordinary and compelling circumstances, nor is the Court convinced that these rise to the level of extraordinary and compelling reasons justifying a sentence reduction. Defendant has similarly failed to show that he does not pose a danger to the community, considering his drug and firearm convictions and his disciplinary infractions while imprisoned; or that a sentence reduction would be consistent with 18 U.S.C. 3553(a) and the applicable policy statements. Finally, Defendant has failed to show that this Court has jurisdiction over any request for home confinement, considering that the BOP is solely responsible for determining an inmate's place of incarceration. See 18 U.S.C. § 3621(b). For these reasons, Defendant's Motion is hereby DENIED without prejudice. Defendant may refile the present motion provided he submits evidence to satisfy the requirements of 18 U.S.C. 3582(c)(1)(A). Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia- Gregory on 12/15/2020. (MQ) (Entered: 12/15/2020)
